Question:
PCE Week 11-Confusion regarding eigenbasis:

It was my understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation. Furthermore an orthonormal eigenbasis for matrix A also represents the same linear transformation. However see Example 3 from PCE 11 below. 

My confusion is because of the calculations I did below. I inputed the same vector into the standard matrix A, The transformation in terms of basis b, the eigenbasis B, and the orthonormal eigenbasis u. I found that none of them are mapped to the same place. Can someone please explain why that is.
Answer:
" Understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation"

This is not accurate. An eigenbasis is a basis for $$\mathbb R^n$$. It does not present a linear transformation. However, one can use it as a basis to represent a linear map by computing their output in the coordinate of the eigenbasis and writing the matrix representation of the linear map with respect to this eigenbasis. 

It seems that you are missing the following important underlying concept: $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ is the matrix of $$T$$ with respect to the basis $$\mathcal B$$. If you plug in $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of a vector it will compute the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate of the output of that vector for you. In your computation, you are plugging in the same coordinates into both matrices. If $$\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\\5\end{bmatrix}$$ is the standard coordinate of your vector, to be able to use $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ to find its output, first you need to find its $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate, and then you can plug it into $$[T]_\mathcal B$$. " Understanding that a matrix A and an eigenbasis for a matrix A represent the same linear transformation"

eigenbasis is a basis for $$\mathbb R^n$$. It does not present a linear transformation. However, one can use it as a basis to represent a linear map by computing their output in the coordinate of the eigenbasis and writing the matrix representation of the linear map with respect to this eigenbasis. 

It seems that you are missing the following important underlying concept: $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ is the matrix of $$T$$ with respect to the basis $$\mathcal B$$. If you plug in $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of a vector it will compute the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate of the output of that vector for you. In your computation, you are plugging in the same coordinates into both matrices. If $$\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\\5\end{bmatrix}$$ is the standard coordinate of your vector, to be able to use $$[T]_\mathcal B$$ to find its output, first you need to find its $$\mathcal B$$ coordinate, and then you can plug it into $$[T]_\mathcal B$$.

Question:
PCE Week 11:

Hi how is [T]B (in terms of B) determined here. I tried finding a change of basis matrix that takes A to B and when I inputed the columns of A, I did not get the columns of the matrix here. Is finding a change of basis matrix not the way to go about this? Any explanation is appreciated, thanks.
Answer:
The columns of the matrix representation of a map with respect to a basis are teh output of vectors in that basis written in terms of the same basis. That is the approach used here as we already know the output of vectors in teh basis $$\mathcal B$$. Alternatively you can find the change of basis matrix $$S$$ from $$\mathcal B$$ to standards and find $$S^{-1}AS$$.  Applying $$S^{-1}$$ to columns of $$A$$  will give you the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of the output of the standard vectors, which doesn't have much to do with $$[T]_\mathcal B$$.

That is the approach used here as we already know the output of vectors in teh basis $$\mathcal B$$. Alternatively you can find the change of basis matrix $S$$ from $$\mathcal B$$ to standards and find $$S^{-1}AS$$. 

Applying $$S^{-1}$$ to columns of $$A$$  will give you the $$\mathcal B$$ coordinates of the output of the standard vectors, which doesn't have much to do with $$[T]_\matcal B$$.

Question:
PCE11-Part II:

Since A is a symmetric matrix, it should have an orthogonal eigenbasis. May I know why the second option is wrong, thanks.
Answer: Symmetrci matrice have orthonormal eigenbasis. That does not mean all of their eigenvectors are orthogonal. Take a map that scales by 2 in $$\mathbb R^2$$ and take any two non-perpendicular vectors.

Question:

In the PCE it implicitly refers to Definition 8.3.1 in the textbook, but seems to contradict the textbook definition and the example at the end:

This is Definition 8.3.1 from the textbook:


This is from the example in the PCE later on:


I assume there is a mistake in the first part of the PCE, or that I missed something when reading the PCE.
Answer: Singular values of $$A$$ are square roots of the eigenvalues of $$A^TA$$. The word "exactly" should be replaced with "closely connected" in the first part.
